results.title: Tomatoes for Troops
results.creator_credit: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Bob Harper
results.brief_description:
This film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an example of propaganda for the war effort, encouraging farmers to grow tomatoes for the armed forces during the Second World War. The film includes footage of soldiers on the Kokoda Trail, and outlines the importance of vegetables for the armed forces in combat overseas.

The film takes the viewer through the stages of tomato production on a mass scale, showing the process of collecting, disinfecting and washing seeds; cultivating and fertilising the soil; planting the seedlings and maximising growth. The film then outlines common diseases and pests that threaten the healthy growth of tomato plants, such as spotted wilt, tomato moths and weevils, along with preventative measures to mitigate these risks.

Finally, the film shows the industrial-scale quality assessment and canning of tomatoes in a factory. The final product, shown in the hands of an active soldier, is a can of SPC peeled tomatoes.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Jack Keane, Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture. Film Unit and Bob Harper

results.title: Return
results.brief_description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.
results.description: Static images of an old country house are combined with voices of the past to evocative effect. Haunting and nostalgic, ‘Return’ conveys the life that exists in old, abandoned places.

results.title: Witness
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Through intermingling static images of a playground, the beach and the town, David Greig paints a picture of Apollo Bay, on the west coast of Victoria, that is evocative and nostalgic.

results.title: Ceremony
results.creator_credit: David Greig and Experimental Film and Television Fund
results.brief_description: Nearly completing his painting, the artist takes a walk outside, where his creativity manifests itself in the life around him. This experimental work captures the ritualistic spirituality of art and the art in the everyday. Paintings in the film are by Paul Mason.

results.title: ACMI Presents: Legends of Australian Animation
results.brief_description:
To celebrate ‘DreamWorks Animation: The Exhibition’, ACMI decided it was a wonderful opportunity to invite five internationally-lauded Australian auteur animators to join us in a celebration of their careers, and to talk about the Australian animation industry.
Oscar winners and nominees Adam Elliot, Bruce Petty, Shaun Tan, Anthony Lucas and Sejong Park share their experiences, expertise and perspectives on their craft, their career histories and their production processes.
The panel was hosted by Melbourne cinematic stalwart Tait Brady.

results.title: Melons for Jam
results.creator_credit: Ann Millard, Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture
results.brief_description: This short film, produced by the Victorian Department of Agriculture, is an instructional film on fruit preserving. Expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates the process for making melon jam in a domestic kitchen. This film is a fascinating insight into household kitchens and cooking in the 1950s, particularly before widespread international food import enabled greater fruit produce availability all year.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Ann Millard, Jack Keane and Victoria. Dept. of Agriculture

results.title: Canning Vegetables
results.brief_description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.
results.description: In this Victorian Department of Agriculture instructional film, expert preserver Gwen McCrorey demonstrates how to process and can a variety of vegetables, including beans, carrots and cauliflower, in a domestic kitchen. The film is an interesting example of a household kitchen and of home cooking in Australia in the 1950s.

results.title: "War Pictures": Australians at the Cinema 1914-1918
results.brief_description:
A compilation of archival films that chronicles the Australian cinema-going experience during WWI from 1914 to 1918.

Between 1914 and 1918, cinema attendance was on the rise and the local film industry was expanding with over 50 Australian feature films produced during the period. While many of these films have been tragically lost, those that remain offer a rare glimpse into Australian life during this turbulent time.

As the war began, filmmakers rushed to make features about Australia’s involvement. Alfred Rolfe’s ‘Hero of the Dardanelles’ (1915) told the story of Gallipoli, complete with landing scenes shot at Tamarama Beach in Sydney.

However, as the years progressed, war-weary audiences lost their taste for patriotic stories, and a new genre of home-grown comedies emerged featuring knockabout characters from the Australian bush. Throughout the war years, Hollywood dramas, serials, love stories and comedies were also staple attractions, and Charlie Chaplin was an international superstar.

War Pictures offers a wide-ranging selection of local and international material, including a focus on Australia’s ‘lost films’.

Specially commissioned introductions and musical accompaniment offer contemporary audiences a chance to step back time and experience cinema as it was enjoyed during the First World War.

This work was shown at ACMI from 10 March to 26 July 2015 in the ‘War Pictures’ exhibition.

results.title: Time changes
results.brief_description: “Time changes” is an experimental, self-reflexive film, comprised of footage filmed over four years by Sue Ford and her friends. Described by the artist as being “a documentary about time and change, focusing on four men who were filmmakers and close friends”, the film features friends Stuart Green, Chris Maudson, John Phillips and Paul Reed, as well as Ford, her children Emma and Ben, and artists Richard Brennan, Bonita Ely, Margo Nash and Ashe Venn. Through unscripted dialogue, the friends’ conversations range across topics such as the integrity of filmmaking and creative practice to ways of living and relationships.

results.title: [William Darbyshire Home Movies: Reel 9]
results.brief_description:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the United States of America taking in the sights of Long Beach, Disneyland, San Francisco and San Diego all in California, USA.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 view of the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco.
00:01:45:00 taxiing airplanes (aeroplane), supply trucks and a Shell brand fuel truck on an airport tarmac.
00:02:03:00 airplane taking off from the tarmac
00:02:10:00 a helicopter on the tarmac
00:02:45:00 views of some sailing yachts and piers
00:03:01:00 signs for Alcatraz businesses followed by a Bay Cruise terminal and passengers
00:03:30:00 a particularly nice Hotel on a town or city corner
00:04:35:00 women with placards marching outside a ‘J C Penney’ store in San Diego
00:05:09:00 San Diego County Courthouse
00:05:33:00 houses along a beach on the Pacific Ocean
00:05:59:00 surf boards for hire on the beach
00:06:59:00 cars and traffic
00:08:02:00 US Navy personal atop a submarine at a dock.
00:08:19:00 a Disneyland engine and train ride
00:08:30:00 views around Disneyland
00:08:51:00 a cable car and pirate ship in Disneyland
00:09:3:00 the Mark Twain paddle steamer in Disneyland
00:10:32:00 a rocket ship in Disneyland
00:11:05:00 Native American dancers performing for an audience in Disneyland

description_for_label:
William (Billy) Darbyshire (1903–1979) was a film enthusiast and traveller who emigrated with his parents from England to Australia in 1911. It may have been this early trip that influenced a young Billy to travel the world later in life and film his travels as he went.

First travelling to Africa for work and to various destinations whilst in service during WWII, Billy would continue to travel after the war throughout Asia, Europe, Africa, the Pacific and North America. It was in this period, during the 1960s, that he purchased an 8mm movie camera which resulted in a collection of films that capture his travels, taking in the sites of the world from Asia to Europe and Africa to the Americas.

The films were originally made using Standard 8mm film. The quality of the film can be a little challenging as it is jumpy, damaged and scratched at times.

In this film, Billy travels to the United States of America taking in the sights of Long Beach, Disneyland, San Francisco and San Diego all in California, USA.

Selected highlights list:
00:00:04:00 view of the Golden Gate Bridge, San Francisco.
00:01:45:00 taxiing airplanes (aeroplane), supply trucks and a Shell brand fuel truck on an airport tarmac.
00:02:03:00 airplane taking off from the tarmac
00:02:10:00 a helicopter on the tarmac
00:02:45:00 views of some sailing yachts and piers
00:03:01:00 signs for Alcatraz businesses followed by a Bay Cruise terminal and passengers
